description: From Middle English can, first and third person singular of connen, cunnen (“to be able, know how”), from Old English can(n), first and third person singular of cunnan (“to know how”), from Proto-West Germanic *kunnan, from Proto-Germanic *kunnaną, from Proto-Indo-European *ǵneh₃- (whence also know). Doublet of con. See also: canny, cunning.

verbs.description: can (third-person singular simple present can, present participle (by suppletion) able, simple past could, past participle (obsolete except in adjectival use) couth)

entries.meaning: (auxiliary verb, defective) To know how to; to be able to.
examples: Synonym: be able to
Antonyms: cannot, can't
She can speak English, French, and German.
I can play football.
Can you remember your fifth birthday?

entries.meaning: (modal auxiliary verb, defective, informal) May; to be permitted or enabled to.
examples: Synonym: may
You can go outside and play when you're finished with your homework.
Can I use your pen?

entries.meaning: (modal auxiliary verb, defective) To have the potential to; be possible.
examples: Can it be Friday already?
Teenagers can really try their parents' patience.
Animals can experience emotions.

entries.meaning: (auxiliary verb, defective) Used with verbs of perception.
examples: Can you hear that?.
I can feel the baby moving inside me.

entries.meaning: (obsolete, transitive) To know.
examples: Synonyms: cognize, grok, ken

description: From Middle English canne, from Old English canne (“glass, container, cup, can”), from Proto-Germanic *kannǭ (“can, tankard, mug, cup”).

entries.meaning: A more or less cylindrical vessel for liquids, usually of steel or aluminium, but sometimes of plastic, and with a carrying handle over the top.
A container used to carry and dispense water for plants (a watering can).
A tin-plate canister, often cylindrical, for preserved foods such as fruit, meat, or fish.
(archaic) A chamber pot, now (US, slang) a toilet or lavatory.
examples: Shit or get off the can.
Bob's in the can. You can wait a few minutes or just leave it with me.

entries.meaning: (US, slang) Buttocks.
(slang) Jail or prison.
examples: Bob's in the can. He won't be back for a few years.

entries.meaning: (slang, in the plural) Headphones.
(archaic) A drinking cup.
(nautical) A cube-shaped buoy or marker used to denote a port-side lateral mark
A chimney pot.
(slang, in the plural) An E-meter used in Scientology auditing.
(US, slang) An ounce (or sometimes, two ounces) of marijuana.
examples: […]  prosecution for selling and giving away marijuana, the evidence clearly constituted substantial proof that a package purchased by defendant contained marijuana where he requested "four cans" of marijuana to be delivered to himself and  […]

entries.meaning: A protective cover for the fuel element in a nuclear reactor.

verbs.description: can (third-person singular simple present cans, present participle canning, simple past and past participle canned)

entries.meaning: To seal in a can.
examples: They canned air to sell as a novelty to tourists.

entries.meaning: To preserve by heating and sealing in a jar or can.
examples: They spent August canning fruit and vegetables.

entries.meaning: To discard, scrap or terminate (an idea, project, etc.).
examples: He canned the whole project because he thought it would fail.

entries.meaning: (transitive, slang) To shut up.
examples: Can your gob.

entries.meaning: (US, euphemistic) To fire or dismiss an employee.
examples: The boss canned him for speaking out.

entries.meaning: (golf, slang, transitive) To hole the ball.
(transitive) To cover (the fuel element in a nuclear reactor) with a protective cover.
